title: 109_hr5284
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that infertility rates have increased, with preventable causes such as STDs and environmental toxins posing a threat to reproductive health. The aging population's fertility complications require preparedness from healthcare providers and government agencies. 10% of infertility cases have unexplained causes, and public awareness can help reduce its incidence. Medical schools often lack resources to adequately train students in infertility causes, treatment, and counseling. SEC. 2. INTERAGENCY INFERTILITY PREVENTION TASK FORCE. The "Infertility Prevention Task Force" is established to develop strategies for the Federal Government to prevent infertility. This includes maximizing cooperation among departments, coordinating research, and promoting public awareness of infertility causes. The "Infertility Prevention Task Force" aims to involve the private sector, create a curriculum for medical schools, and establish partnerships with various entities to collect and share information on infertility prevention. The Task Force consists of 10 members, including the Assistant Secretary for Health. The "Infertility Prevention Task Force" consists of 10 members, including representatives from the National Institutes of Health, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, and Environmental Protection Agency. The "Infertility Prevention Task Force" includes a member from the Association of American Medical Colleges appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and four obstetrics-and-gynecology physicians specializing in fertility techniques and infertility prevention appointed by various congressional leaders. The "Infertility Prevention Task Force" is chaired by the Assistant Secretary for Health and members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members cannot receive compensation. The Task Force must meet at least four times a year at the Chairperson's call. The Infertility Prevention Task Force must meet at least four times a year with a quorum of six members. They are required to submit annual reports to Congress detailing their activities, findings, recommendations, and policies. The Task Force will terminate upon the submission of the final report.
